title: How can a person’s perception actually be their reality when it is so clear to others around them that it is truly a false perception? - Quora

response.answer_text: People can perceive the same thing quite differently, such as witnesses at a traffic incident, views on a political candidate, or views on any controversial subject. Maybe how we perceive ourselves - and how others perceive us - is more controversial than we thought?! We had just assumed the views were more or less congruent — well maybe not? Things might be worse than we thought. Or better than we thought. The problem may be something that should be there but isn’t. Or with something that shouldn’t be there that is there. The problem may be with the person who is being perceived by others. But the problem could be with the onlookers. Or some of both. Or neither. We have to “consider the source” of the comments, whether they might be prejudiced or have hidden agendas to make us feel good or bad about ourselves. People’s perception of self (or others) is colored by FILTERS of past experience and life conditioning, including traumas, hopes and fears, positive or negative attitudes, biases of attention, prejudices, absence of relevant past experience, failure to check their appearance from all angles in a mirror and in different lighting, failure to get a wide variety of feedback in life, etc. On the other hand, it’s OK to be different, unless it’s an “emperor has no clothes” situation. In the case of absence of relevant experience, a person doesn’t know what they’re missing, and doesn’t even know that they’re missing something. Introverts, people who don’t speak up and share authentically, but instead withhold or hide within themselves, may be misunderstood since what others see for good or ill on the outside may not be what’s going on for the person inside. People who are arrogant or overconfident usually don’t perceive this about themselves, but it’s obvious to others who may be offended by those attitudes and behaviors. Arrogance can be the flip-side of shyness, an overcompensation for shyness or feeling like they’re not enough just as they are. The incongruity can be so severe that no one wants to talk about it. The topic becomes the elephant in the room, an “undiscussable.” As the therapists say,,”What’s not being talked about is running everything.”

This means they believe the false perception is real no matter what other people say, because that's how most people dream. This occurs more so when someone is hallucinating while awke, because they don't expect to be dreaming while their awake. Some people have the ability known as lucid dreaming, which means their aware their dreaming/hallucinating, this usually occurs when something impossible happens in their dreams, prevoking the idea their hallucinating. However, for people suffering from psychotic disorders, this rarely happens. Therefore since they believe their hallucinations to be real they'll act like it's real, which is why people with those disorders are so irrational while expericing these perceptions, and hard to convince that their hallucinating. The question is, “How can a person’s perception actually be their reality when it is so clear to others around them that it is truly a false perception?” To quote the poet Robert Burns, O wad some Power the giftie gie usTo see oursels as ithers see us! —To a Louse: On Seeing One On A Lady's Bonnet, At Church For each one of us, the one thing we know for certain is that we exist, think, and perceive. Thus, our own perception is, naively, our reality. That is the condition of the newborn. As we grow up, we begin to understand that there is some sort of external reality that feeds us milk, changes our diapers, picks us up, puts us in bed, and so on. To express this at greater length, We asserted earlier that there is at least one absolute existential truth: one’s own existence. We said further that the proof of this is one’s consciousness. But what is the nature of that existence? Most of us believe that existence extends beyond our own consciousness. Indeed, the modern western reader may object, “We all know that physical existence is the true reality, and consciousness a product of it.” Let us consider that notion, starting from the only truth of which we can be absolutely certain: our own existence. Why do we accept that physical existence is a reality at all, let alone the true or primary reality? The answer is not difficult: if I try to act as though my consciousness is the only reality, I get bad results. Contrast, for example, the dream (or daydream), in which I am able to fly, against the waking result of flapping my arms and jumping. Even if nobody else is present to give me feedback, I perceive that there is some external reality that is different in the waking state than in the dream state. From infancy on, we progressively learn the nature and boundaries of a personal realm and a shared realm. Through direct experience, observation, discussion, and reading, we find that this view is shared by others, and we come to accept the existence of a physical realm as a truth about reality. The existence of a physical realm does not by any means prove, however, that consciousness is a product of physical existence. All it proves is that reality is larger than our own personal existence (consciousness). It does not provide any clue as to the true nature of our personal existence or of physical existence, or to whether physical existence is a cause of consciousness, a result of consciousness, or neither. The nature of reality and its relationship to consciousness are among the existential questions that will be addressed later. For the moment, we wish simply to emphasize that materialism—that is, the currently dominant conception of reality as primarily physical, with all other aspects of reality being by-products of physical existence—is simply a conception, a set of beliefs, which, like all beliefs, should be examined carefully in our search for truth. Materialism, like Newtonian physics, may turn out to be a very useful approximation to reality when applied to the proper domain, but inappropriate and inaccurate in other domains. —Truth: A Path for the Skeptic, Reality. Here is one description of our true reality: Whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth is a direct evidence of the revelation within it of the attributes and names of God…. To a supreme degree is this true of man, who, among all created things, hath been invested with the robe of such gifts, and hath been singled out for the glory of such distinction. For in him are potentially revealed all the attributes and names of God to a degree that no other created being hath excelled or surpassed. All these names and attributes are applicable to him. Even as He hath said: “Man is My mystery, and I am his mystery.” Manifold are the verses that have been repeatedly revealed in all the Heavenly Books and the Holy Scriptures, expressive of this most subtle and lofty theme. Even as He hath revealed: “We will surely show them Our signs in the world and within themselves.” Again He saith: “And also in your own selves: will ye not, then, behold the signs of God?” And yet again He revealeth: “And be ye not like those who forget God, and whom He hath therefore caused to forget their own selves.” In this connection, He Who is the eternal King—may the souls of all that dwell within the mystic Tabernacle be a sacrifice unto Him—hath spoken: “He hath known God who hath known himself.” —Gleanings from the Writings of Bahá’u’lláh, number XC. In brief, our true reality is such that if we truly knew that reality, we would know God! Therefore, if our perceptions were finely tuned, they really would be our reality. Unfortunately, that is not how we generally orient ourselves, and so, we have distorted perceptions, both of ourselves and of those around us. The best we can do is to look to improve our own character, while overlooking what we perceive to be faults in those around us. O Emigrants! The tongue I have designed for the mention of Me, defile it not with detraction. If the fire of self overcome you, remember your own faults and not the faults of My creatures, inasmuch as every one of you knoweth his own self better than he knoweth others. —The Hidden Words, Persian #66. Here is advice from one who spent much of his life in exile and prison for his religious beliefs: Soon will your swiftly passing days be over, and the fame and riches, the comforts, the joys provided by this rubbish-heap, the world, will be gone without a trace. Summon ye, then, the people to God, and invite humanity to follow the example of the Company on high. Be ye loving fathers to the orphan, and a refuge to the helpless, and a treasury for the poor, and a cure for the ailing. Be ye the helpers of every victim of oppression, the patrons of the disadvantaged. Think ye at all times of rendering some service to every member of the human race. Pay ye no heed to aversion and rejection, to disdain, hostility, injustice: act ye in the opposite way. Be ye sincerely kind, not in appearance only. Let each one of God’s loved ones center his attention on this: to be the Lord’s mercy to man; to be the Lord’s grace. Let him do some good to every person whose path he crosseth, and be of some benefit to him. Let him improve the character of each and all, and reorient the minds of men. In this way, the light of divine guidance will shine forth, and the blessings of God will cradle all mankind: for love is light, no matter in what abode it dwelleth; and hate is darkness, no matter where it may make its nest. O friends of God! That the hidden Mystery may stand revealed, and the secret essence of all things may be disclosed, strive ye to banish that darkness for ever and ever. —Selections from the Writings of ‘Abdu’l‑Bahá, Selection 1.

If you subscribe to the quantum physics notion of the observer being an integral part of the event and determining at least part of the outcome, a person’s personal “reality” makes perfect sense. If you subscribe to he notion that a person has a particular perception of the world that becomes “real” to them, that’s also fine. And it explains a lot of how to deal with folks’ opinions and reactions. However, if a person’s reality is that the really, really, really know they can fly, their perception will likely be irrelevant as soon as it contacts the ground. The basic idea is one of context. Many people seem to claim that “their reality” is something that the rest of the world simply has to accept as valid. But that’s 1) not likely to persuade people who they’re trying to persuade, and 2) not something many of us, such as myself, give a rat’s $#*(#$* about. We may know someone is very committed to a certain view and how it affects them, but there are other people in the world. As far as I know, there are quite a few of them, and their priorities are not necessarily subject to one person’s “personal truth”. Which can result in problems for that one person.

Our inaccurate expressions often create epistemic problems for us, for others, all around us. Check on your words with respect to what I have to say below. Anybody’s perception isn’t infinite. It doesn’t reveal complete reality, nor it is meant for that. A perception depicts a search for the relevance. Just as you pick up a coin from within a lump of garbage, a perception is a pick, not an unlimited involvement. So, a perception reveals partial reality, however small or large it may be. A perception is currently the handle of reality, because of its “relevance”. The reality, however large it may be, offers itself to be handled through the perceived point. Perception of partial reality has been often wrongly described as “false perception”. It is an incomplete perception, not a false perception.

Because part of their perception includes the opinion that the perceptions of others that are communicated to the person and in opposition to that person’s belief system have no bearing on how that person sees reality. In other words, this person clearly doesn’t care what others think, and doesn’t care that he/she doesn’t care. Additionally, those people who perceive what they believe to be this person’s reality cannot actually see that person’s reality, they can only see the reality created by their own perceptions and opinions. In other words, the onlookers are in the exact same position as the one they critique.

What if there is no such thing as perception, and it only appears this way that there is a subject “here” perceiving an object “there”? What if the subject, perception and object are merely deduced as an attempt to explain the fact that experiences are happening, but in reality there is nothing apart from the experiences themselves?

It is wrong to say that someone has "his own" reality. There is only one objective reality that can be easily verified at the empirical level, and can be carried forward by logical reflection at a more abstract level, which of course must be consistent with the empirical basis and not contradictory to itself. To return to the original question: The question itself is based on a subjectivist worldview that implies something that is not correct, namely that the existence of reality is inevitably identical with one's own perception, or that it may not be possible to verify it in principle. This is not true.
